title: 112_s922
content: The "Urban Jobs Act of 2011" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings and purposes related to urban job creation. Congress finds that one-third of minority youth are unemployed, the labor force participation rate is lower for individuals without a high school diploma, African-American and Hispanic students have a lower graduation rate, high school dropouts cost the nation billions in lost wages, and urban high school graduation rates are below the national average. High school dropouts earn significantly less over their lifetime compared to graduates. The national high school graduation rate is 70 percent, below the average of 60 percent for urban districts. High school dropouts earn significantly less over their lifetime, with 75 percent of State prison inmates and 59 percent of Federal prison inmates not completing high school. Increasing the high school completion rate can save the US billions annually and reduce crime rates significantly. The purpose of this Act is to provide resources to prevent disproportionate youth incarceration. The male high school graduation rate can reduce arrest rates for murder, assault, motor vehicle theft, and arson. The purpose of this Act is to provide resources for national nonprofit organizations to prevent disproportionate youth incarceration and prepare them for employment or education leading to economic self-sufficiency. SEC. 173B. URBAN JOBS PROGRAMS under the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 aims to provide resources for national nonprofit organizations to prevent youth incarceration and help them prepare for employment or education leading to economic self-sufficiency. The purpose of this section is to provide competitive grants for establishing a feeder system for youth aged 18-24 in urban communities, to prepare them for employment or education leading to employment, prevent disproportionate youth incarceration, and provide holistic services. The definition of a community-based affiliate is also provided. To prevent disproportionate youth incarceration in urban communities, grants are provided for community-based affiliates working with eligible youth aged 18-24 not in school or involved in the criminal justice system. Eligible youth are defined as individuals in this age group. The Urban Jobs Program grants are provided to community-based organizations with expertise in outreach to eligible youth in urban communities. Recidivism is defined as a tendency to return to criminal behavior, and an unsubsidized job is one that pays wages without public funds. The Urban Jobs Program grants are awarded to national intermediaries on a competitive basis to fund comprehensive programs for eligible youth in urban areas, providing a pathway to employment or education leading to employment. To be eligible for a grant, national intermediaries must submit an application with required information as specified by the Secretary. To receive a grant under this subsection, a national intermediary must submit an application with specified information to the Secretary. The application must include a request for the grant amount and proposed uses, as well as a description of how the intermediary will meet goals for participants in the Urban Jobs Program, such as increased long-term employment, reduced recidivism, improved education attainment, and literacy. The curr_chunk describes the outcomes expected from the Urban Jobs Program, including increased employment in unsubsidized jobs, reduced recidivism, improved education attainment, literacy, and attainment of industry-recognized certificates. It also outlines the necessary supports for the program, such as engaged community partners, staff expertise in youth development, and understanding of youth characteristics. The Urban Jobs Program aims to help participants achieve outcomes like creating caring relationships, setting goals for employment or education, and obtaining industry-recognized certificates. The Urban Jobs Program aims to help participants achieve outcomes such as completion of a degree, attainment of industry-recognized certificates, community service, workplace skills development, responsibility for one's future, and goal-setting strategies. The Urban Jobs Program aims to help participants develop workplace skills, responsibility for their future, goal-setting strategies, reduce risk-taking behaviors, improve educational and employment outcomes, and reduce recidivism through activities leading to industry-recognized certificates or credentials. The Urban Jobs Program includes case management and educational services to help participants attain industry-recognized certificates and reduce recidivism. The Jobs Program offers educational services like skill assessment, remediation, and career pathway connections, employment activities such as mentoring and training, and support services like health referrals and housing assistance. The Urban Jobs Program provides internships, training, personal development, and support services such as health referrals, substance abuse counseling, housing assistance, and transportation. Additionally, reports on program progress are submitted to relevant committees annually. The Secretary of Labor will submit a report to relevant committees detailing the progress of establishing Urban Jobs Programs through national intermediaries. The program is not subject to evaluations required under section 172. A National Jobs Council Advisory Committee will be established with 11 members appointed by the Secretary, including individuals from the private sector with experience in hiring and employee oversight. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members from the private sector, employers in high-growth industries, national intermediaries, and representatives from the Department of Labor. Members serve for the life of the Committee, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Committee's duties include analyzing and preparing recommendations for the Secretary on various workforce-related matters. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee consists of 11 members appointed for life. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Committee analyzes program design, strategic priorities, and formulates guidelines. Members do not receive compensation for travel expenses. The Committee prepares periodic reports with recommendations and members receive travel expenses but no compensation. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement. The Secretary may accept voluntary services of Committee members without compensation. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement. The Committee is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Congress recommends establishing local advisory committees for community-based affiliates receiving funding. Employers in high-impact industries should make up at least one-third of the committee members. The section establishes a local jobs council advisory committee to support and guide the program, with at least one-third of members being employers in high-impact industries. Funding for urban jobs programs is authorized for fiscal years 2012-2016. Sec. 173B authorizes funding for urban jobs programs from 2012-2016.
